awd_titl_txt: Central Valley Region Interdisciplinary Science Education Research Symposium
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI Program), this conference seeks to serve the national interest by bringing together researchers, educators, students, and leaders throughout California’s Central Valley to offer an opportunity for significant interdisciplinary and cross-campus collaborations that will meet the needs of the undergraduate student population. Within this region there are more than 25 institutions of higher education, from community colleges to research universities, ranging in size from under 3,000 to more than 25,000 undergraduate students. All these institutions serve a student population that is highly diverse, historically underserved, and representative of America’s current and future demographics. The development of this symposium will be a cooperative effort between five of these Central Valley institutions (Fresno City College, Merced College, California State University (CSU) Stanislaus, CSU Fresno, and University of California (UC) Merced). Three of these institutions (CSU Stanislaus, CSU Fresno, and UC Merced) have received NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (IUSE-HSI) Track 3 grants. Unfortunately, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, researchers from these grants have had few opportunities to share the important work that they have accomplished on these projects.  Therefore, the goals of the symposium are to: (1) disseminate education research findings from the Central Valley community, investigate trends in education research, and identify future directions for education research and practice; (2) encourage and facilitate networking and new interdisciplinary research collaborations among faculty, staff, and students from Central Valley two-year and four-year institutions that results in rigorous research that addresses some of our nation’s most pressing education needs; and (3) provide a space for undergraduate and graduate students to discover and better understand the field of educational research and potential career pathways. 

Given our desire for this symposium to become an annual event, it will be important to assess how well the symposium meets both the outcomes listed above and meets the needs and expectations of the participants. To assess the effectiveness of the symposium, we plan to collect participant demographics, pre- and post-surveys of participants’ expectations, and track long- term impact metrics and dissemination records. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education, broaden participation in STEM, and build capacity at HSIs. Achieving these aims, given the diverse nature and context of the HSIs, requires innovative approaches that incentivize institutional and community transformation and promote fundamental research (i) on engaged student learning, (ii) about what it takes to diversify and increase participation in STEM effectively, and (iii) that improves our understanding of how to build institutional capacity at HSIs are supported by this program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
CVRISER Overview

Providing students with a high-quality education is integral to the success of any college or university, and yet what makes teaching and learning effective is not intuitive for most instructors prepared outside of Schools of Education. Evidenced-based education research is on the rise in many disciplines and aims to identify effective instructional strategies and pedagogical approached that facilitates deep learning. In the California?s Central Valley, discipline-based education research is still in its nascent stages, so it is critical to establish and nurture a community that focuses on evidence-based education principles and strategies that positively impacts students across this region. To create a community with this focus, we developed the Central Valley Regional Interdisciplinary Symposium on Education Research (CVRISER).

 

CVRISER is a gathering of 2- and 4-year Minority-Serving (MSIs) and Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs). Faculty, students, staff, and administrators share the goal of fostering a budding education research community in a historically underserved region dedicated to supporting these students. CVRISER was co-created, developed, and organized by 3 California Central Valley institutions that have received NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (IUSE-HSI) grants: University of California, Merced, California State University, Stanislaus, and California State University, Fresno. CVRISER was first hosted by UC Merced in the summer of 2022 after the campus received a Howard Hughes Medical Institution Inclusive Excellence (HHMI IE). The 2023 conference was hosted at Fresno State, from June 23?25. Additional collaborators include a group of regional community colleges including Fresno City College, Madera College, Clovis College, and Merced College. New collaborators this year include Bakersfield College and California State University, Bakersfield.

 

CVRISER Outcomes 

  1. Disseminate education research findings from the Central Valley community, investigate trends in education research, and identify future directions for education research and practice. 
  2. Encourage and facilitate networking and new interdisciplinary research collaborations among faculty, staff, and students from Central Valley two-year and four-year institutions that results in rigorous research that addresses some of our nation?s most pressing education needs. 
  3. Provide a space for undergraduate and graduate students to discover and better understand the field of educational research and potential career pathways. 

 

Intellectual Merit 

Education research is interdisciplinary by nature, requiring expertise in content, pedagogical methodologies, and empirical data collection and analysis. As a result, it relies on methods from diverse fields, such as psychology, economics, mathematics, computer science, cognitive science, sociology, engineering, chemistry, mathematics, physics, and biology. Even so, most college structures impede such interdisciplinary research, and the interdisciplinary connections necessary to carry out this research across the Central Valley are yet to be formed. CVRISER is an opportunity for interdisciplinary and cross-institution collaborations that meets the needs of the Central Valley student population.  

 

This conference fostered the development of a young, but growing, community by bringing education researchers together to share their work and formulate new, collaborative research projects. This conference stimulated rich interdisciplinary dialog across various campuses and research areas, including biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics, engineering, education, sociology, psychology, cognitive sciences, and discipline-based education research (DBER). In addition to featuring keynote talks and major thematic symposia, this conference generated new collaborations, new disciplinary research interests, and new research topics that directly affect student success from historically underrepresented students the Central Valley.  

 

Broader Impacts 

Given the demographics of California?s Central Valley region, the development of an education research community has huge implications for understanding how students from historically underrepresented groups learn and succeed, particularly. Intentionally creating spaces for both 2- and 4-year institutions to discuss student success and education strategies closes opportunity gaps for transfer students and promotes cross-campus collaborations to explicitly support these students.
